chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Next we will talk about unary operators.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Unary operators need only a single operand to perform their function.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Unary operator sounds new, strange and weird but it is very easy.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: It is basically a simple way of writing a plus 1 is equal to a.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Whenever we want to write a plus 1 is equal to a, we can write a plus plus or plus plus a.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Whenever we want to write a is equal to a minus 1, we can write a minus minus or minus minus a.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So in a way, when our first operand can be anything but the second operand is always 1,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: then we know that we have to perform the function on only one operand.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: We have to work on a only. We know that the second operand is automatically 1.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: That's why it is called unary operator.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So a plus 1 is equal to a. The simple way to write a is a plus plus.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: If you want to increase or decrease the value of any variable by 1,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: then we will either write plus plus or minus minus.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: We call this plus plus as increment operator because it increases the value.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: And we call this minus minus as decrement operator because it decreases the value by 1.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Now increment and decrement operators have two subtypes.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: First, let's talk about the increment operator.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Increment operator is of two types.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: First is pre-increment and the second type is post-increment.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Pre means before and post means later.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So increment operator follows a rule.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: What does pre-increment operator do?

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: First of all, it will change the value.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: That is, the value of the unary operation you want to perform will change first.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: And after that, the value will be used.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Plus plus is before, which means the value will change first and then the value will be used.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: What does this mean?

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: This means that if I define a variable int a is equal to 10,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: and I define another variable b is equal to plus plus a,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: and then if I want to print b,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: then first I print a, then I print b.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So here the value of a was printed 11 and the value of b was also printed 11.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So what did this statement do?

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: This statement increased a by 1.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So a value increased from 10 to 11 and then it assigned that 11 value to b.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Let's understand this with a little diagram.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: What did we do?

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: First we defined a is equal to 10.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: After that, we wrote int b is equal to plus plus a.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So what did we understand the meaning of plus plus a?

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: It means a plus 1.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: The value a plus 1 will be used after the change.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: That is, first of all, in the memory,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: where a is stored and its value is 10,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: first that value will be cut to 10 and 11 will be stored there.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: And after that, in b, where there was no value,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: there will be the same 11 stored there.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So when we printed a, we got 11 prints.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: And when we printed b, we got 11 prints there too.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Why? Because first of all, the value of a will change and then it will be used.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: First of all, a will change itself and then its updated value 11 will be used to assign b.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Whenever we change first and then use it later, we call it pre-increment.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: That is, you increased it earlier and then used that value.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Its second type is post-increment.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: In post-increment, this plus plus comes after the variable.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: The rule of post-increment says that first we will use the old value and then we will change the value of the variable.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So first the old value of the variable will be used and then the value of the variable will be updated.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: For this, we write the same code again, but this time we will write a plus plus.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: If I copy this code and write a plus plus here,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: then in this case, when I print a, I will get 11 prints, but when I print b, I will get 10 prints.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Why did this happen?

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: This happened because if we do a plus plus in our memory, then a is assigned 10 in the beginning.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: And when it comes a plus plus, then the value of a should be a plus one.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: But Java will make b before doing a plus one.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So first b will be made, then the value of a in b will be assigned.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Means its old value will be used.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: The old value of a is 10, so first 10 will go inside b.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: After that, the value of a will change.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Means as the value of b is assigned, b will be made in the memory, after that the value of a will change.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: After that, 11 will be stored in b instead of 10.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Then we will come to the next line.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: In the next line, we will check that the value of a will be printed 11,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: but if we check the value of b, then it was assigned before a was incremented.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So there will be 10 printed for us.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So in post increment, first we use the old value.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Means to make b, the old value of a was used.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: After that, we change the value.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: That's why its name is post increment.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: That's why the plus plus is kept after a.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: In the same similar manner, we have our decrement operator.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: The same rule of decrement operator remains.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Pre means before.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So what will happen before?

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: First, our value will be changed.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: And after that, we will use our new updated value.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: What will happen in post decrement?

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: First of all, we will use our old value.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: And after that, we will change or update the value of our variable.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Let's see an example of this.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: First of all, if I take an integer a,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: is equal to 10.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: After that, I took an integer b,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: is equal to minus minus a.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: And if I print the value of a,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: and after that the value of b.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So the result of this is 9 and 9.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Because minus minus a, means the pre decrement operator,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: will change the first value.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Then we will use it to make b.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: But here, if instead of minus minus a,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: we use a minus minus, then what will happen?

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: In that case, in b, only 10 is stored.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Only a value changes.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Because to make b, only one old value is used.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: That is, 10 is used.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: So this difference occurs in unary increment and unary decrement.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: In this also, we have to take special care of pre and post.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: In our expressions, whether we are using pre or post,

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: sometimes it brings a slight change.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: Because of which the code can get disrupted.

chunks.title: Unary
chunks.text: That is why we have to keep our basics very clear from the beginning.

text: Next we will talk about unary operators. Unary operators need only a single operand to perform their function. Unary operator sounds new, strange and weird but it is very easy. It is basically a simple way of writing a plus 1 is equal to a. Whenever we want to write a plus 1 is equal to a, we can write a plus plus or plus plus a. Whenever we want to write a is equal to a minus 1, we can write a minus minus or minus minus a. So in a way, when our first operand can be anything but the second operand is always 1, then we know that we have to perform the function on only one operand. We have to work on a only. We know that the second operand is automatically 1. That's why it is called unary operator. So a plus 1 is equal to a. The simple way to write a is a plus plus. If you want to increase or decrease the value of any variable by 1, then we will either write plus plus or minus minus. We call this plus plus as increment operator because it increases the value. And we call this minus minus as decrement operator because it decreases the value by 1. Now increment and decrement operators have two subtypes. First, let's talk about the increment operator. Increment operator is of two types. First is pre-increment and the second type is post-increment. Pre means before and post means later. So increment operator follows a rule. What does pre-increment operator do? First of all, it will change the value. That is, the value of the unary operation you want to perform will change first. And after that, the value will be used. Plus plus is before, which means the value will change first and then the value will be used. What does this mean? This means that if I define a variable int a is equal to 10, and I define another variable b is equal to plus plus a, and then if I want to print b, then first I print a, then I print b. So here the value of a was printed 11 and the value of b was also printed 11. So what did this statement do? This statement increased a by 1. So a value increased from 10 to 11 and then it assigned that 11 value to b. Let's understand this with a little diagram. What did we do? First we defined a is equal to 10. After that, we wrote int b is equal to plus plus a. So what did we understand the meaning of plus plus a? It means a plus 1. The value a plus 1 will be used after the change. That is, first of all, in the memory, where a is stored and its value is 10, first that value will be cut to 10 and 11 will be stored there. And after that, in b, where there was no value, there will be the same 11 stored there. So when we printed a, we got 11 prints. And when we printed b, we got 11 prints there too. Why? Because first of all, the value of a will change and then it will be used. First of all, a will change itself and then its updated value 11 will be used to assign b. Whenever we change first and then use it later, we call it pre-increment. That is, you increased it earlier and then used that value. Its second type is post-increment. In post-increment, this plus plus comes after the variable. The rule of post-increment says that first we will use the old value and then we will change the value of the variable. So first the old value of the variable will be used and then the value of the variable will be updated. For this, we write the same code again, but this time we will write a plus plus. If I copy this code and write a plus plus here, then in this case, when I print a, I will get 11 prints, but when I print b, I will get 10 prints. Why did this happen? This happened because if we do a plus plus in our memory, then a is assigned 10 in the beginning. And when it comes a plus plus, then the value of a should be a plus one. But Java will make b before doing a plus one. So first b will be made, then the value of a in b will be assigned. Means its old value will be used. The old value of a is 10, so first 10 will go inside b. After that, the value of a will change. Means as the value of b is assigned, b will be made in the memory, after that the value of a will change. After that, 11 will be stored in b instead of 10. Then we will come to the next line. In the next line, we will check that the value of a will be printed 11, but if we check the value of b, then it was assigned before a was incremented. So there will be 10 printed for us. So in post increment, first we use the old value. Means to make b, the old value of a was used. After that, we change the value. That's why its name is post increment. That's why the plus plus is kept after a. In the same similar manner, we have our decrement operator. The same rule of decrement operator remains. Pre means before. So what will happen before? First, our value will be changed. And after that, we will use our new updated value. What will happen in post decrement? First of all, we will use our old value. And after that, we will change or update the value of our variable. Let's see an example of this. First of all, if I take an integer a, is equal to 10. After that, I took an integer b, is equal to minus minus a. And if I print the value of a, and after that the value of b. So the result of this is 9 and 9. Because minus minus a, means the pre decrement operator, will change the first value. Then we will use it to make b. But here, if instead of minus minus a, we use a minus minus, then what will happen? In that case, in b, only 10 is stored. Only a value changes. Because to make b, only one old value is used. That is, 10 is used. So this difference occurs in unary increment and unary decrement. In this also, we have to take special care of pre and post. In our expressions, whether we are using pre or post, sometimes it brings a slight change. Because of which the code can get disrupted. That is why we have to keep our basics very clear from the beginning.
